dublinCore.dc:title: 118 HR 5009 IH: Wildlife Innovation and Longevity Driver reauthorization Act
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Joyce of Ohio (for himself, Mrs. Dingell, Mrs. González-Colón, Mr. Costa, Mr. Carter of Georgia, Mr. Thompson of California, and Mr. Garbarino) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Natural Resources

form.official-title: To reauthorize wildlife habitat and conservation programs, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Wildlife Innovation and Longevity Driver reauthorization Act or the WILD Act.

section.header: Partners for Fish and Wildlife Act
section.text: Section 5 of the Partners for Fish and Wildlife Act (16 U.S.C. 3774) is amended by striking 2019 through 2023 and inserting 2024 through 2028.

subsection.text: Section 2101 of the African Elephant Conservation Act (16 U.S.C. 4211) is amended by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text: The Secretary may award to a person who is otherwise eligible for a grant under this section a multiyear grant of up to 5 years to carry out a project that the person demonstrates is an effective, long-term conservation strategy for African elephants and the habitat of African elephants.
Nothing in this subsection precludes the Secretary from awarding a grant on an annual basis.

subsection.text: Section 2306(a) of the African Elephant Conservation Act (16 U.S.C. 4245(a)) is amended by striking 2019 through 2023 and inserting 2024 through 2028.
Section 5 of the Asian Elephant Conservation Act of 1997 (16 U.S.C. 4264) is amended by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text: The Secretary may award to a person who is otherwise eligible for a grant under this section a multiyear grant of up to 5 years to carry out a project that the person demonstrates is an effective, long-term conservation strategy for Asian elephants and the habitat of Asian elephants.
Nothing in this subsection precludes the Secretary from awarding a grant on an annual basis.

subsection.text: Section 8(a) of the Asian Elephant Conservation Act of 1997 (16 U.S.C. 4266(a)) is amended by striking 2019 through 2023 and inserting 2024 through 2028.

section.header: Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act of 1994

subsection.text: Section 5 of the Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act of 1994 (16 U.S.C. 5304) is amended by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text: The Secretary may award to a person who is otherwise eligible for a grant under this section a multiyear grant of up to 5 years to carry out a project that the person demonstrates is an effective, long-term conservation strategy for rhinoceroses or tigers and the habitat of rhinoceroses or tigers.
Nothing in this subsection precludes the Secretary from awarding a grant on an annual basis.

subsection.text: Section 10(a) of the Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act of 1994 (16 U.S.C. 5306(a)) is amended by striking 2019 through 2023 and inserting 2024 through 2028.
Section 4(j)(1) of the Great Ape Conservation Act of 2000 (16 U.S.C. 6303(j)(1)) is amended by inserting of up to 5 years after multiyear grant.
Section 6 of the Great Ape Conservation Act of 2000 (16 U.S.C. 6305) is amended by striking 2019 through 2023 and inserting 2024 through 2028.
Section 4 of the Marine Turtle Conservation Act of 2004 (16 U.S.C. 6603) is amended by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text: The Secretary may award to a person who is otherwise eligible for a grant under this section a multiyear grant of up to 5 years to carry out a project that the person demonstrates is an effective, long-term conservation strategy for marine turtles, freshwater turtles, or tortoises and the habitat of marine turtles, freshwater turtles, or tortoises.
Nothing in this subsection precludes the Secretary from awarding a grant on an annual basis.

subsection.text: Section 7(a) of the Marine Turtle Conservation Act of 2004 (16 U.S.C. 6606(a)) is amended by striking 2019 through 2023 and inserting 2024 through 2028.
